text: the weakened echoes of silence hi
everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's
busiest music nerd in it's time for an
album review the weekend echoes of
silence the weekend is a Canadian
experimental R&B project fronted by
vocalist and songwriter able to say hey
this is not the first time I'm running
into this project though I did a review
the month this project dropped its debut
release house of balloons and to be
honest it was one of my most negative
reviews of last year not only that but I
think it was definitely in the top 5 for
biggest negative backlash from viewers
and yeah you know I said the weekend was
a group possibly during a time when how
many people were involved and who was
involved wasn't common knowledge but
that wasn't a big issue the big issue
was just people angry and confused over
how I could not like this release
wha-ah-ah how could I possibly say there
might be auto-tune used as an effect not
a crutch somewhere on some of these
songs
moral of the story people hate differing
opinions but I love them so so yeah I
didn't like house of balloons I thought
it was really nice that this project
wanted to experiment with R&B sounds and
emotions and subject matters but in a
way I just felt like it kind of went
horribly horribly wrong I mean the album
shop for dark moody and depressing but I
think it just ended up sounding kind of
whiny a little douchey and it was mostly
because of the lyrics a lot of misogyny
and drug endorsements and partying and
trivial relationship stuff not that
those subject matters are bad but I felt
like they weren't really handled with
all that much poeta sysm I just felt
like some of the lyrics were really
trashy
and shallow what do you want I still
came away from this thing thinking you
know this guy's experimenting he's got
his own style and whether or not I like
a weekend album I've got to respect that
then the EP Thursday dropped about five
months later and you know the production
was noticeably better it got up to a
little bit but I was still catching a
lot of lyrics on these tracks that I
didn't care for even Drake who was one
of the guys who originally co-signed
this project appeared on here spitting a
verse and you know honestly I liked
hearing the weekend on Drake stuff more
than I like hearing the Drake on the
weekend stuff I didn't review Thursday
but I didn't come away hating it I just
kind of felt like I was on the fence
with it so just before Christmas the
weekend drops this new tape brand new
tape echoes of silence and I liked it a
lot ah-oh
and I think echoes of silence pushes
past the previous two releases in every
way the production on this thing is a
lot better just the sounds are larger
the atmosphere is more vast and some of
the vocal effects that really annoyed me
on previous weekend releases are just
not here I feel like echoes is way more
upfront with Abel's voice it feels more
nude I guess sure there are some edits
and some spots of reverb here and there
on his voice that are very apparent but
his voice just feels really bare and to
prove how great the vocals are in the
weekend the project faces its biggest
challenge yet and that's a Michael
Jackson cover of the song Dirty Diana
and that's kind of fitting when you
consider what the weekend usually sings
about but still huge shoes to fill it's
the King of Pop off-the-wall thriller
and bad or killer albums
and not just anybody can step up to bat
on these songs in my opinion I think the
weekend passes with flying colors on
this track it has the explosion of drama
and catchiness that the original does
but it has this dark sad depression that
the weekend is known for brought into
the equation Abel's voice
some range show some really eerie
similarities to Michaels and it's so
close sometimes it's almost like
listening to a remix and with all these
heavy beats and rising cents and really
chilly background vocals it's an
excellent take on the song it almost
feels like industrial at some spots but
still after the cover was over I figured
you know I'm not going to like the rest
of the songs the lyrics are going to be
different the vocals are going to be
different it's not going to be a song
I'm already familiar with it's just
going to go downhill but that wasn't the
case though I feel like instead of
falling back on its usual R&B flavor the
weekend sticks with pop on the second
track Montreal here the weekend crafts
are really lean and memorable pop tune
with relatable lyrics it's not just a
really uneventful song where you get a
repetitive B for five minutes with
nothing but just vocalizing about a drug
binge over it the song Montreal opens up
with lyrics sung in French and then
develops into this kind of tasteful
story about loneliness love and a
relationship on the rocks and even when
this thing gets on the subject of sex on
the next track
it doesn't feel cheap like previous
weekend tracks it's not like I'm hearing
lyrics like [ __ ] you right instead I'm
hearing this story about how one person
is sleeping with another despite the
fact that there are memories of an ex in
that person's head and kind of the sour
addition to the stories that both people
know the same goes for the party tracks
on this album they don't really feel
cheap or shallow I actually feel the
depression this time the situation
actually feels serious the party isn't
fun anymore all the drugs alcohol and
sex are leading to addiction drained
bank accounts and lost time your father
doesn't know where you are there's no
rent money your mother is crying because
she found your bag of weed and the
laundry I feel like these moments are
painted with the same powerful imagery
that Danny Brown pulled out on tracks
like party all the time and nosebleed
off of the triple XL let me drop last
year and of course the synthesizers and
the beat behind this track are just huge
and mournful it's like they're kind of
acknowledging that the person being sung
about in the song is already dead but
the thing is it's not over the drugs and
the sex and the twisted nosov the lyrics
on this album gets even deeper on the
next song
I mean Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas
requiem for a dream kind of twisted and
it's interesting because as the drugs
are getting heavier on the fifth track
initiation the vocals are getting all
manipulated and pitch shifted in really
unpredictable directions almost like the
listener is tripping out along with the
person being son about it's kind of
disturbing and when the song ends
this release slips into slightly less
unsettling territory with same old song
which is kind of a personal story about
passing up the chance to be with a girl
who didn't want you when you were
nothing but now that you're something
she's calling and that's not really the
most unique story in music but what's
kind of funny is that I feel like that
gets acknowledged in the hook talking
about how this girl and the situation
itself is like the same old song and I
like the able is just really belting out
these lyrics over the hook I mean I am
really feeling this hook threw him off I
love how he left all of his really huge
breaths in while he was singing that
hook it just really kind of made a feel
even more emotive to just it just felt
really just really crushing of course
really moody instrumental helps the
situation it has this really lumbering
beat very kind of subtle icy guitar in
the background the song the fall is okay
I wish it was more eventful but the beat
is decent produced by clams Casino and
it does have an interesting story
showing that there's always kind of a
shade of doubt in the background
somewhere no matter how confident the
weekend gets the track talks about Fame
being kind of like a drug high and it
doesn't last forever in fact pretty much
every song from track 6 to track 9 talks
about how Fame has somehow changed ables
love life or personal life and it's not
like he comes off cocky or insecure or
overcompensating like some artists sign
it's more like listen you're only trying
to get with me because I'm starting to
get popular it's not going to last
forever anyway you're crazy echoes of
silence brings the personality the
lyrics and the level of production I
would have liked to have heard from this
project in the first place but you know
it's been pretty interesting following
the weekends exploits up until this
point and the fact that I thought this
thing was great only kind of makes my
mouth water even more when I think about
the album the weekend has coming out
later this year so as far as R&B goes
the weekend is definitely more creative
sound rich and more interesting than any
other R&B artist out there I feel like
that was true since house of balloons
but at this point with echoes of silence
I feel like that actually means
something right now I feel like this is
the bar and it's set here I'm feeling a
decent two strong 8 on this thing
thought it was great but um let me know
what you think do you love it
do you hate it why what do you think I
should review next do you feel like
there's actually been a noticeable
improvement a change in this project or
am I just crazy and liking it all of a
sudden I don't know Anthony Fantana The
